main_text:
Values, such as liberty and equality, are sometimes said to be
incommensurable in the sense that their value cannot be reduced to a
common measure. And options, such as studying to become a lawyer or
studying to become a philosopher, are sometimes said to be
incomparable in the sense that neither option seems to be at least as
good as the other. These possibilities are thought to raise deep
questions about practical reason and rational choice as well as
related questions concerning topics as diverse as akrasia,
moral dilemmas, the plausibility of utilitarianism, and the
foundations of liberalism. This entry outlines answers in the
contemporary literature to these questions, starting with questions
about the nature and possibility of these phenomena.
